Article.ArticleTitle: Ozone induces stomatal narrowing in European and Siebold's beeches: a comparison between two experiments of free-air ozone exposure.

AbstractText: Stomata tend to narrow under ozone (O(3)) impact, leading to limitation of stomatal O(3) influx. Here, we review stomatal response under recently conducted free-air O(3) exposure experiments on two species of the same tree genus: Fagus sylvatica at Kranzberg Forest (Germany) and F. crenata at Sapporo Experimental Forest (Japan). Both beeches exhibited reduction in stomatal conductance (gs) by 10-20% under experimentally enhanced O(3) regimes throughout the summer relative to ambient-air controls. Stomatal narrowing occurred, in early summer, in the absence of reduced carboxylation capacity of Rubisco, although photosynthetic net CO(2) uptake rate temporarily reflected restriction to some minor extent. Observed stomatal narrowing was, however, diminished in autumn, suggesting gradual loss of stomatal regulation by O(3). Monotonic decline in gs with cumulative O(3) exposure or flux in current modeling concepts appear to be unrealistic in beech.
